journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Experimental evaluation of parameter identification schemes on a direct-drive robot

article-meta.aff: 1Centro de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Universidad Autónoma de San Luis Potosí, Mexico
2Grupo de Robótica, Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla, Mexico
3Departamento de Investigación en Física, Universidad de Sonora, Mexico
4Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Autónoma de San Luis Potosí, Mexico

author-notes.corresp: César A Chávez-Olivares, Centro de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad Autónoma de San Luis Potosí, Av. Manuel Nava 8, Zona Universitaria, San Luis Potosí, S.L.P. 78290, Mexico. Email: iescd.chavez@gmail.com

abstract.p: The dynamic and friction parameters of a robot are used in advanced control schemes, and their accuracy significantly affects their performance. These parameters can also be used for a realistic simulation. In principle, the numerical value of the parameters could be obtained via computer-aided design analysis but inevitable assembly and manufacturing errors exist. Direct measurement is not a realistic option because the complex nature of the system would involve an intense time-consuming effort. Alternatively, we can deduce the values of the parameters by observing the natural response of the system under appropriate experimental conditions, that is, by using identification schemes. This article presents the experimental evaluation of five identification schemes used to obtain the dynamic and friction parameters of a two-degree-of-freedom, direct-drive robot. We assume that the dynamic and friction parameters are totally unknown but, by design, the dynamic model is fully known. We consider the schemes based on the dynamic regression model, filtered-dynamic regression model, supplied-energy regression model, power regression model, and filtered-power regression model. The article presents a comparison between experimental and simulated robot responses, which enable us to verify the accuracy of each regression model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Advanced control schemes for robot manipulators, such as computed torque control and feedforward dynamic compensation, require accurate information on the robot dynamics.1,2 An accurate system-identification process is a crucial step required to improve the performance of such control schemes, while enabling a realistic robot simulation. Dynamic parameters can include mass, inertia tensor, length, and center of gravity of each link, as well as friction coefficients. The value of such parameters is, in general, not known in advance, even by the robot manufacturer. Often, the only model available is the kinematic model of the manipulator. The direct measurement of the dynamic parameters is not a realistic option, because assembling and disassembling the robot is not an easy task. Also, a computer-aided design (CAD)–based model is insufficient because inevitable assembly and manufacturing errors exist. Therefore, identification techniques for robot manipulators are particularly attractive to determine the dynamic parameters of robot manipulators when a direct measurement of the parameters of each link is not a viable solution. In this context, an experimental identification scheme is the most practical alternative.

A crucial aspect in robotic identification is that the nonlinear ordinary differential equations describing the dynamic model of a manipulator with revolute and prismatic joints can be expressed in a linear fashion with respect to the unknown dynamic parameters. The friction is a complex nonlinear phenomenon that has several representations; among these, there are dynamic models such as the LuGre model proposed in Canudas et al.3 However, for control applications, it is useful to have simple models that capture the essential properties of friction.4 Two examples included in the traditional model are the linear viscous friction model and the Coulomb friction model. Also, by using this friction model, the friction phenomenon can be described in a linear fashion with respect to the unknown Coulomb and viscous friction parameters, which are consistent with the linear model structure.

There are identification schemes that exploit the property of linearity of the dynamic model with respect to the constant parameters. For example, early work requiring joint acceleration information within the regression model is referred to as dynamic regression model or differential regression model.5,6 The first approach relaxing joint acceleration, referred to as filtered-dynamic regression model, was proposed by Hsu et al.7

The total energy applied to robot manipulators can be described by a linear regression model that combines dynamic and friction parameters. Such a form was used to propose the supplied-energy regression model,8 also known as the integral model.5 Both the filtered-dynamic model and the energy model are regression models independent of joint acceleration. It is well known that the supplied-energy model leads to a scalar prediction error, while the filtered-dynamic model leads to a vector prediction error.

Another regression model based on the principle of energy conservation was proposed by Reyes and Kelly.9 That regression model was referred to as filtered-power model, and this was derived from the supplied-energy model proposed by Gautier and Khalil.8 The supplied-energy model involves the integral of the power, while the filtered-power model contains a low-pass filter of the power.

In the literature, there are references related to the identification of robots; however, during the last decade, only a few works include an experimental comparison with various regression models. In earlier articles, we can read about the experimental comparison between filtered-dynamic and supplied-energy models on a direct-driven, two-link robot.5 As shown in this reference, the filtered-dynamic model has advantages with respect to the supplied-energy model. In Kozlowski and Dutkiewiez,6 both regression models were tested on a nondirect-drive robot and concluded that the filtered-dynamic model has advantages over the supplied-energy model.

Reyes and Kelly9 presented a comparison, based on experimental evidence, between three regression models tested in a two-degree-of-freedom, direct-drive robot. In this work, the tested regression models were the filtered-dynamic, the supplied-energy, and the filtered-power models. These schemes belong to the hybrid identification philosophy,10 that is, the estimation is performed by a recursive estimator while the regression model is formulated in continuous time. They concluded that the filtered-dynamic scheme provided better parameter estimates, with increased complexity in the implementation. The other regression schemes reduce the computational process and are more suitable for real-time implementation. Also, if Coulomb friction is present, the filtered-power model offers advantage over the approach based on the supplied-energy model. Note that in Reyes and Kelly,9 the identified parameters were compared to those obtained by measuring the link parameters and later used to reproduce simulated results, which are compared with the current experimental data. A difference in the behavior was observed.

Recent approaches in dynamic parameter identification consider direct and indirect identification processes. In the indirect identification process, the system parameters are individually identified in multiple steps. The identification trajectories usually consist of one or two joint motions at the time, which can be generated by simple controllers. Examples of such identification methods can be found in Benimeli et al.,11 Grotjahn et al.,12 and Kinsheel and Taha.13

On the other hand, the direct identification methods are based on a single-motion trajectory that excites all the parameters of the robot dynamics. The challenging part of this method is the design of the identification trajectory that leads to an optimum estimation of the system parameters. The trajectory optimization problem is addressed in several research works.14–17

In Wu et al.,18 the authors present an overview of dynamic parameter identification of robots. They classified methods as off-line and online and discussed about trajectory optimization. In Bingül and Karahan,19 we found a comparison between the two methods to estimate only the inertial parameters of an industrial robot: least squares method and particle swarm optimization. They concluded that the accuracy of the estimated parameters depends on the estimation methods, measurement accuracy, and the selection of efficient exciting trajectories. Other interesting approaches can be found in the literature, for example, the study by Choi et al.20 presents a method to estimate individual parameter values based on dependency analysis of the regressors, based on measured motion trajectory data. In Gautier et al.,21 the authors proposed a new method for parameter identification that uses only the force/torque measurement. The method is based on a closed-loop simulation using the direct dynamic model, the same structure of the control law, and the same reference trajectory.

In this article, a procedure to obtain the parameter identification of a robot manipulator is presented. Therefore, the main goal of this work consists of presenting an experimental comparison of off-line robot dynamic estimation, considering the following five identification schemes: dynamic model, filtered-dynamic model, supplied-energy model, power model, and filtered-power model. Such hybrid identification schemes can be considered as direct identification processes. In these schemes, the same estimator, the recursive least squares algorithm, is implemented. We assume that the dynamic and friction parameters of our experimental direct-drive arm are unknown. In order to validate the parameter values obtained from the best regression scheme, we compare open-loop joint positions of the actual robot with simulations, using the robot model with these identified parameters. Another procedure for validating the identified parameters consists of reproducing the applied torque from the torque computed with the dynamic model. This comparison is also presented. The last step of the procedure consists of the use of two new identification schemes, based on momentum and Hamiltonian equations; these identification schemes constitute another contribution of this article.

sec.title: Dynamic model for direct-drive robots
sec.p: The dynamic analysis of the robot arm determines a relationship between the joint torques/forces applied by the actuators and the motion of the robot. The motion of the robot is described by the joint positions, joint velocities, and joint accelerations of the robot arm as a function of time. Robot manipulators have complex nonlinear dynamics that complicates the implementation of accurate and robust control schemes. Fortunately, robot dynamic model can be obtained in a straightforward way by using, for example, Lagrange motion equations.
The dynamics of a serial n-link rigid robot can be written as

where q∈ℝn×1 is the vector of joint displacements, q·∈ℝn×1 is the vector of joint velocities, q··∈ℝn×1 is the vector of joint accelerations, τ∈ℝn×1 is the vector of applied generalized forces/torques, M(q)∈ℝn×n is the symmetric positive definite manipulator inertia matrix, C(q,q·)∈ℝn×n is the matrix of centripetal and Coriolis torques, g(q)∈ℝn×1 is the vector of gravitational torques obtained as the gradient of the robot total potential energy U(q), and f(q·)∈ℝn×1 is the friction torque vector. In this article, we consider the common Coulomb and viscous friction models, that is
where

It is well known that is possible to define combinations of model parameters such that the dynamic model (1) is linear with respect to each combination. The complete set of parameters describing the mass distribution is referred to as barycentric parameters. The dynamic model contains only a few independent combinations of these barycentric and the friction parameters as follows
where Y(q,q·,q··)∈ℝn×p is a matrix of known functions, while θ∈ℝp×1 is a vector containing combinations of barycentric and friction parameters.

sec.title: Parameter identification
sec.p: In this section, seven identification schemes based on seven different regression models, whose parameters were determined by using a recursive least squares approach, are presented. An overview of the recursive least squares method and the formulation of regression models is presented in the following.

sec.title: Recursive least squares algorithm
sec.p: The least squares method is a standard technique used to obtain an approximate solution of overdetermined systems. Least squares method computes the minimum of squared errors sum; the error is defined as the difference between measured data and the computed data using the mathematical model, in our case, the dynamic model of robots. If the model has the property of being linear in the parameters, then the method is particularly simple. Let us consider the following regression model

where y(k)∈ℝn represents a output vector, Ψ(k)∈ℝp×n is the regressor matrix of known functions, and θ∈ℝp is the vector of unknown parameters. The model (5) is indexed by the variable k, which denotes the sampling time. It will be assumed that the index set is a discrete set.
The value of θ^ can be computed using the recursive least squares method. The matrix P(k)∈ℝp×p is called covariance matrix
where the prediction error e(k) is defined as

sec.title: Dynamic and filtered-dynamic regression models
sec.p: The robot dynamic model (1) describes the relationship between torques applied to the joints and the resulting motion of the links. The representation of the robot dynamic model given in equation (4), which relates joint torques with the unknown dynamic parameters, is referred to as the differential regression model5,22,23 and can be written as
to coincide with the above notation from section “Recursive least squares algorithm.” The prediction error for the dynamic regression model can be written as

In this regression model, in order to compute the elements of the matrix regressor Y(q,q·,q··), a measurement of joint acceleration q·· is required. In order to avoid this drawback, the filtered-dynamic regression model has been proposed in the literature.7

The principal idea is to filter both sides of the differential regression model (9) by a stable, strictly proper filter. A simple first-order filter has been considered in the literature. The filter has been denoted by its transfer function
where λ>0 and s stands for the Laplace variable.
Therefore, the filtered-dynamic regression model can be written as
where

Note that the measurement of joint acceleration q·· is not required to compute regressor Yf(q,q·) and that all initial conditions are considered zero. Using the above notation and the recursive least squares method (6) to (8), the prediction error for the filtered-dynamic regression model can be written as

sec.title: Supplied-energy regression model
sec.p: The supplied-energy regression model introduced by Gautier and Khalil8 is based on the principle of conservation of energy. The work of the nonconservative forces applied to a system is equal to the change of the total energy of the system

Using the property of linearity in the parameters of the robot total energy,9 the principle of conservation of energy (15), and assuming that the total energy at the instant zero is null, we obtain the supplied-energy regression model8
which is linear in the barycentric and friction parameters. Note that in order to compute the regressor, the measurement of joint acceleration q·· is not required.
The prediction error of the supplied-energy regression model, to be used in the recursive least squares algorithm, can be written as
where h denotes the sampling period.

sec.title: Power and filtered-power regression models
sec.p: By using the supplied-energy regression model (16), we can compute the power applied to the manipulator. The power applied to the robot is the instant change on the total supplied energy
and the prediction error for power regression model can be written as
This model presents the drawback of requiring the joint acceleration measurement in order to compute the matrix regressor.

The filtered-power regression model was proposed by Reyes and Kelly9,24 based on the supplied-energy regression model and overcomes this shortcoming. The principal idea is to filter both sides of the power model (18) via a stable, strictly proper filter. Again the first-order filter described in equation (11) can be considered.
By applying the filter to both sides of equation (16), we obtain the filtered-power regression model

The above model is linear in the barycentric and friction parameters. Also, in order to compute the regressor matrix, the measurement of q·· is not required. The scalar prediction error of the filtered-power regression model can be written as

sec.title: Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models
sec.p: In this section, we present two new regression schemes based on the Hamilton motion equations for robot manipulators.25 These schemes are referred to as the Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models.
The prediction error for the Hamiltonian regression model can be written as
Using a stable, strictly proper filter on the Hamiltonian regression model (22), the filtered-Hamiltonian regression model results, whose prediction error is given by

sec.title: Experimental platform
sec.p: The experimental results are presented on a direct-drive vertical robot that was designed and built at the Robotics Laboratory of Benemérita Universidad Autónoma de Puebla (BUAP). The two-degree-of-freedom robot “Rotradi,” consisting of two 6061 aluminum links, was actuated by brushless direct-drive servo actuator in order to drive the joints without gear reduction26 (Figure 1). The motors used in “Rotradi” are the DM-1150A and DM-1015B models from Parker Compumotor for the shoulder and elbow joints, respectively. The servos are operated in torque mode, which means that the motor acts as a torque source, and they accept an analog voltage as a reference of torque signal. The features of the servo actuators are shown in Table 1. The robot system has a device designed for reading the encoders and generates reference voltages, which is a motion control board of Precision MicroDynamics, Inc. The control algorithms are written in C code and run in real time with 2.5 ms sample period on a Pentium-1 at 166 MHz.

The complete dynamic model of the experimental arm has been developed considering that the links do not have a specific shape, that is, links are considered like rigid bodies without a specific mass distribution. The entries of the robot dynamics are given as
where the time-invariant barycentric and friction parameters θi,i=1,…,10 are given by

In identification schemes, the choice of input trajectories for exciting the robot is very important. A good selection of trajectories leads to an accurate model-parameter determination. For our identification problem, the required trajectories are referred to as weakly persistent excitation trajectories. The selection of this kind of trajectories is not trivial due to its complexity.
Guided by practical experience, we propose a procedure for tuning the torque trajectory. The mathematical structure of the torque trajectory can be given by

where α1j,α2i,w1j,w2i,β1,β2∈ℝ, i=1,2,3 and j=1,2,…,5. This mathematical structure is based on linear combinations of examples of excitation-persistent signals described in Goodwin and Sin27 and Âström K and Wittenmark.28
The excitation trajectory for each joint is tuned considering many experiments such that

list-item.p: In order to obtain the adequate amplitude of the torque trajectory, parameters α1j,α2i,w1j,w2i,β11,β21∈ℝ must ensure that the motion of the robot is within the servomotor bandwidth for all joints. These parameters are chosen such that ∑j=15α1j<|τ1max|=150Nm and ∑i=13α2i<|τ2max|=15Nm, where τ1max and τ2max represent the maximum limits for shoulder and elbow joints, respectively. The parameters w1jandw2i are irrational frequencies and β1 and β2 denote the time constants.

sec.p: Extensive experiments were carried out with several torque trajectories that contain sinusoidal functions with different frequencies to excite the system. The best result of parameter identification was obtained by using the following trajectories

where ran1 takes random values with uniform distribution within the interval (−50∘,…,0∘), ran2 within (60∘,…,100∘), ran3 within (5∘,…,35∘), and ran4 within (−30∘,…,30∘). Guided by practical experience, a range chosen of random phase ranging between 30° and 60° leads us to good results. Also, since the torque frequencies are obtained independently from a modal analysis of the robot, there is no evidence of a relationship between these frequencies and the natural frequencies of the robot. The same excitation trajectory was used for the five identification schemes.
It is important to note that the resulting motion of the robot considers the following aspects:

list-item.p: Good coverage of the workspace improves the information content of the measurements as well as the accuracy of the parameter estimates. In Swevers et al.,17 the authors recommend that the covered workspace matches with the space used for a typical task for the robot. In our case, the robot does not have any constraint in joint position; however, the movement of both the joints has covered approximately 30% of a complete revolution.
High accelerations are required to accurately estimate the moments and products of inertia.

Joint velocity must be within the actuator’s bandwidth and lower than the lowest resonance frequency of the robot structure. The structural flexibilities of the robot are excited close to the lowest resonance frequency. Excitation of flexible modes is disadvantageous because they are not accounted for in the rigid-body robot model.

sec.p: Each joint has incremental encoders to measure the joint position and each encoder has 1,024,000 cycles per revolution (cpr) resolution (see Table 1). The joint velocity was computed by using a standard backward difference algorithm applied to position measurement. In the experiments, the arm started its motion according to the following initial conditions: q(0)=0 and q·(0)=0. The aforementioned regression schemes are presented in detail in the following sections.

sec.title: Dynamic regression model
sec.p: The prediction error for the dynamic regression model is described in equation (10). For our robot arm, the regressor is given by

sec.title: Filtered-dynamic regression model
sec.p: The prediction error for the filtered-dynamic regression model is described by equation (14). For our robot arm, the regressor is given by
where
where f1(s)=sλ/(s+λ) and f2(s)=λ/(s+λ).

Since the measured value of joint torques, positions, and velocities hold constant between sampling instants, filters must be implemented in a discrete form. Actually f1(z−1)=λ(1−z−1)/(1−e−hλz−1) and f2(z−1)=(1−e−hλ)z−1/(1−e−hλz−1) are the discrete forms of filters f1(s) and f2(s), respectively.

sec.title: Supplied-energy regression model
sec.p: The prediction error of the supplied-energy regression model is given by equation (17). For our robot arm, the regressor is given by
where
The integrals have been implemented with standard trapezoid-type integration rule.

sec.title: Power regression model
sec.p: The prediction error of the power regression model was defined in equation (19). For our robot arm, the regressor is given by

sec.title: Filtered-power regression model
sec.p: The prediction error of the filtered-power regression model was defined in equation (21). For our robot arm, the regressor is given by
where
The filters f1(s) and f2(s) shown in the above expressions are implemented in the same way as the filtered-dynamic model.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: In this section, we compare the experimental results obtained from the identification schemes described in section “Experimental platform.” The best results were obtained with the filtered-dynamic model. Such a conclusion is based on the comparison between the experimental data and simulated dynamic behavior with the identified parameter values. We define the error between simulated and experimental positions as

which are composed of k samples of the experiment. Two criteria are used to determine which is the best regression scheme. The first criterion is related with the Euclidean norm of error ||qerrori||2, while the second uses the norm L2 of error defined as L2{qerror}=1T∫0TqerrorTqerrordt, the numerical values are shown in Table 2, which are consistent with the results, the integral have been implemented with standard trapezoid-type integration rule. The cutout frequency for the filtered schemes was chosen as λ=9.11rad/s. This value was selected by testing several frequencies; the one enabling a closer approximation between simulated dynamics and real response was chosen.

caption.p: Quantization of error between experimental and simulated positions

sec.p: Table 3 shows the results for different identification schemes, the dimensional units are implicit for all data parameters. As mentioned above, the measuring instrument for the experiment is an incremental encoder used to measure position, while velocities and accelerations are computed using numerical differentiation. Each encoder has 1,024,000 cpr, enabling a numerical accuracy of 6.1359×10−6rad/cycle; for this reason, the results are presented to the sixth digit of precision.

Figure 2 shows the evolution of the parameter vector θ with respect to time. Parameter θ5 has been scaled by a factor of 0.1 for presentation purposes, that is, to show values in a similar scale as the rest of the parameters.

caption.p: Evolution of the parameter vector with respect to time.

sec.p: An important property of the least squares algorithm is that convergence is guaranteed when weakly persistent exciting condition is satisfied.27 Such property can be written as
which is directly related to
In order to show the convergence of the recursive least squares algorithm, we have included a plot with the evolution of the covariance matrix eigenvalues P(k) (see Figure 3).

caption.p: Evolution of the covariance matrix eigenvalues.

sec.p: A proof that validates the parameter values obtained with the regression schemes consists of comparing the open-loop responses of the actual robot with simulations using the robot model together with the identified values. In our case, the regression model with the best simulation response, as compared with actual robot response, was the filtered-dynamic regression model followed by the filtered-power regression model. A 4/5-order Runge–Kutta algorithm implemented in MATLAB 2009 was used in simulations. We also used trajectories (27) and (28) in order to produce open-loop responses in shoulder and elbow joints, respectively. Simulated and actual robot responses are shown in Figure 4; the results for filtered-dynamic regression model are shown in Figure 4(a), while the results for the filtered-power regression model are shown in Figure 4(b). For the other schemes, the plots are not shown since the identified parameters do not have a physical interpretation, for instance, negative friction coefficients.

caption.p: Experimental and simulation responses using excitation trajectories (27) and (28): (a) filtered-dynamic regression model and (b) filtered-power regression model.

sec.p: In the robotics literature, it is common to show a comparison between joint torque and the reconstructed torque using the dynamic model of robot (1) and the experimental data. Identification schemes are used to compute dynamic parameter values for the purpose of applying advanced control laws in manipulator robots. Advanced control laws depend on the dynamic model and their parameter values, for example, computed torque control. In our case, we show in Figure 5 a comparison between input and computed torques using trajectories (27) and (28).

caption.p: Input and reconstructed torques using trajectories (27) and (28).

sec.p: In order to compute the torque value, experimental values of positions, velocities, and accelerations were used. Only positions are measured directly. Velocities and accelerations are computed via numerical differentiation. It is well known that numerical process can induce noise in data torque computation, which is reflected in plots of the reconstructed torque. Another reason that could explain the noise in the plots is that, by design, input trajectories (27) and (28) have a noisy phase. However, the estimated noisy joint acceleration contributes more than the noisy phase in the reconstruction of torque.
The dynamic model using numerical values of parameters obtained with the filtered-dynamic regression model (see Table 3) and L1=0.45m can be written as

In order to strengthen the validity and accuracy of the estimated parameters, we performed an experimental test in open-loop control of the robot manipulator. In this experiment, if the measured response is similar to the simulated response, evidence exists on the accuracy of the estimated parameters but not a definite proof. The reference trajectories qr=[qr1qr2]T used in this experiment are given as follows

For the above position-reference trajectories, we must consider reference velocities and accelerations that can be obtained from analytic differentiation with respect to time. Open-loop control torques τr can be written in the following form, using also the identified parameters

The actual robot and simulation responses are shown in Figure 6. As shown, both responses are similar but not identical, which means that the robot has not been perfectly characterized. Achieving a perfect match is unrealistic as it implies a perfect model and also that complex phenomenon, such as friction, corresponds exactly to the proposed representation. In this case, the mathematical description of this phenomenon is not unique and difficult to model in practice. As mentioned above, the best results obtained through a large number of experiments are presented.

The torque applied to the joints and the torque reconstructed with the dynamic model are shown in Figure 7. The computed torque is noisy because velocities and accelerations have been computed by using a numerical procedure.

In order to add a validation step on the identification procedure, we have used the Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models. Both regression models require the measurement of generalized momentum p, and only one needs its difference with respect to time p·. We do not have a momentum sensor, instead of this, we used the parameter values θ1,…,θ4 obtained with filtered-dynamic regression model to compute inertia matrix M(q) and then we computed p=M(q)q· and p·=M(q)q··+M·(q)q·. The other parameters were estimated with Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models.
In our case, the elements of generalized momentum vector p are given by
and the differences with respect to time are given by
furthermore
where
For our robot arm, the prediction error of the Hamiltonian regression model is given by
where
Also, the prediction error of the filtered-Hamiltonian regression model is given by
where hfi,j=f(s)hi,j,i=1,2andj=1,…,6.

Table 4 shows the estimated parameters obtained with Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models. The standard variation of the identified parameters with respect to values obtained with the filtered-dynamic regression model is shown in Table 5.

As we can see in Table 5, the filtered-Hamiltonian regression model presents less variation in estimated parameter values (9.63%) with respect to the filtered-dynamic regression model than the Hamiltonian regression model (22.10%). However, it is necessary to interpret correctly the results since the first five regression models are used to identify all the parameters of the dynamic model. The Hamiltonian regressor could not be compared with the other because they are used in a verification procedure, and they are formulated based on the fact that a subset of the dynamic model parameters is known.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, we have presented the experimental evaluation of five direct identification schemes used to determine the dynamic parameters of a two-degree-of-freedom, direct-drive robot.

The recursive least squares algorithm was used for all the identification schemes that are dynamic, filtered-dynamic, supplied-energy, power, and filtered-power models. The design of the weakly persistent excitation trajectories is strategic. The appropriate selection of this kind of trajectories determines the accuracy of the identification process.

From the experimental comparison, we consider that the filtered-dynamic model scheme presented the best results in the estimated parameters, because with the parameters obtained with this regression model, we can reproduce the experimental response in simulation of an open-loop control experiment, as shown in Table 2 that contains numerical values of quantization error. Table 5 shows the standard variation with respect to values obtained by using the filtered-dynamic model scheme. The filtered-power regression model presents less variation in parameter values as compared to the filtered-dynamic regression model; the dynamic regression model presents a large variation with respect to the filtered-dynamic regression model, followed by the power regression model. This can be explained by considering that the joint velocity and the joint acceleration are estimated by using a numerical procedure. In order to compute the dynamic regression model and the power regression model, the measurement of joint accelerations is needed, and the noise induced in the numerical procedure reduces the quality of the estimation algorithm.

We have also presented two new regressors based on Hamilton motion equations in order to validate the identification procedure. The regression models are the Hamiltonian and filtered-Hamiltonian regression models; both are expressed in terms of generalized momentum. When the best identification scheme is validated, in this case the filtered-dynamic regression model, we identify a subset of vector parameters using the other subset to compute some terms of the observation vector. Filtered-Hamiltonian regression model presents less variation in parameter values as compared to the filtered-dynamic regression model; in this sense, the filtered-Hamiltonian regression model presents better results than the Hamiltonian regression model.

In general, the five identification schemes based on the aforementioned five regressors could be applied to identify systems in which it is possible to obtain the dynamic model or the energy model in a linear fashion, with respect to the dynamic parameters. Once these basic models are determined, the others can be obtained by applying the corresponding mathematical procedures, that is, the differentiation with respect to the time for the power model and the filtering process for the filtered regression models. The most important limitation to obtain good results with models in which the acceleration is required is related with the instrumentation of the system. In the case of robot manipulators, commonly, the only available instrumentation consists of encoders used to measure the joint positions.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research was partially funded by the CONACyT (México), the ECOES program, the FAI from the UASLP, and the VIEP-BUAP with the project referred to as “Modelado dinámico y simulación de robots manipuladores”.
